Science STEM College RMIT University Melbourne Australia School of Science, STEM College, RMIT University, Melbourne, Australia * Corresponding author Developing multifunctional electrocatalysts toward energy-related reactions could reduce the cost and improve the utilization efficiency of raw materials. Herein, defective CoP decorated with ultrafine Pt nanoparticles (Pt/d-CoP/NPC) with multifunctional electrocatalytic performances is prepared via facile pyrolysis and following chemical reduction process. The as-synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC owns high half-wave potential of 0.82 V for oxygen reduction reaction with excellent stability in 0.1 mol/L KOH. Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that the adsorption energy of *OO at Pt/d-CoP/NPC is stronger compared to Pt, yielding higher catalytic activity for ORR. Moreover, the resultant electrocatalyst possesses excellent catalytic activities with low overpotentials toward hydrogen evolution reaction (33 mV in 1 mol/L KOH, 6 mV in 0.5 mol/L H2SO4 and 70 mV in 1 mol/L PBS) and oxygen evolution reaction (320 mV) at 10 mA/cm2. Water-splitting and rechargeable Zn-air batteries assembled with the as-synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC as electrodes exhibit outstanding activity and long-range stability. Remarkably, sustainable energies and homemade Zn-air battery can efficiently drive the Pt/d-CoP/NPC electrolyzer with sumless hydrogen bubbles generated, verifying the potential applications for renewable energy storage. Graphical Abstract The efficient catalyst of Pt/d-CoP/NPC exhibits excellent full-pH HER and basic OER and ORR performances that are applied in a two-electrode device of overall water splitting and rechargeable Zn-air battery. Keywords Trifunctional electrocatalyst Hydrogen/oxygen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction Flexible Zn-air battery CoP 1 Introduction At present, the global energy shortage and environmental pollution issues have increased research efforts to exploit alternative sustainable and clean energy conversion and storage technologies, involving electrocatalytic water-splitting, metal-air battery and fuel cells [1–4]. Generally, the above technologies own their core electrode reactions, for example, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [5–8]. However, the slow reaction kinetics of the above core reactions hindered the performances of the above devices [9,10]. Currently noble metal-based catalysts, for example, Pt, Ru and Ir are the standard catalysts toward the above electrode reactions [11–14]. Nevertheless, the high cost and scarcity limited their practical application in energy devices [15,16]. Reducing the loading of noble metals is widely recognized as a valid approach to achieve outstanding catalytic activities but decreasing the cost [17–20]. Most of the exploited electrocatalysts exhibit single functionality (such as Pt/CoP-catalysts) [21–25], and then complicate the device construction, increase the cost and lower the performance [26–29]. Therefore, developing electrocatalyst with multifunctional catalytic activities for HER/OER/ORR is a pressing task to simplify the electrodes for the energy storage and conversion devices [30–36]. Various approaches have been explored to construct multifunctional electrocatalysts, such as interfacial engineering [37,38], doping [39,40], introducing defects [41,42], designing special supports [43,44] and constructing specific nanostructures [45,46]. Typically, decorated noble metals onto specific support is a promising avenue to boost the electrocatalytic performances, owing to the electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI) which can cause favorable electronic perturbations [47–49]. Thus, many kinds of supports, such as metal oxide [50,51], metal [52,53], graphene [54,55] and zeolite [52,56], are explored to exhibit the EMSI effects on enhancing the electrocatalytic performance. For instance, Sun and co-authors [57] anchored Pt nanoparticles (Pt NPs) onto lithium cobalt oxide (Pt/LiCoO2) via wet-chemical process. The authors declared that the active sites switched between Pt and LiCoO2 during the HER and OER reactions, respectively, and then the designed Pt/LiCoO2 exhibits excellent catalytic performances toward overall water-splitting. Except electronic interactions, the support also serves as co-catalyst to optimize the catalytic activity. Then, it is also a key task to regulate the catalytic properties of the co-catalyst. Creating defects in the designed nanomaterials is considered as an efficient approach to promote the catalytic process by regulating the electronic structure and inherent properties [58–60]. Relative to anionic defects, the cationic defects are scarcely reported owing to their high formation energy [61,62]. Therefore, exploiting proper support with defects coupled with low-loading noble metals would achieve splendid catalytic performance. Herein, surface-enriched ultrafine Pt-nanoparticles decorated onto N, P co-doped carbon-supported defective CoP was prepared by simple calcination and oil bath chemical reduction strategy (Fig. 1 (a)). The electronic interactions between cobalt and platinum are found to accelerate catalyst kinetics. Moreover, the created cationic defects also suggested to have a pivotal role in enhancing the catalytic activity. Defective sites are able to capture and anchor Pt because the presence of zinc defects changes the electronic structure and coordination environment, resulting in the emergence of vacant and unsaturated coordination sites as “trap” to anchor Pt [63–65]. Controllable architectural defects can effectively promote ion diffusion and charge transfer, as well as provide more storage sites/adsorption sites/active sites for metal ions or intermediates, and are beneficial to maintain the structural flexibility and stability of materials, so as to boost the catalytic performance [66,67]. Eventually, the as-prepared Pt/d-CoP/NPC exhibit multifunctional catalytic activities toward oxygen reduction reaction, oxygen evolution reaction and hydrogen evolution reaction. The overall water splitting cells and flexible Zn-air batteries employing the designed Pt/d-CoP/NPC as the electrode electrocatalyst also present remarkable performances. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Melamine phosphate (MP) was obtained from Rhawn Co, Ltd. Chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O), zinc chloride (ZnCl2) and cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O) was provided by Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co, Ltd. The Pt/C (20%) was obtained from Shanghai Macklin Bio-Chem Co., Ltd. The RuO2 (99.9%) was obtained from Sigma-aldrich (Shanghai) Trading Co., Ltd. The ethylene glycol (99.5%) was provided by Sinopharm Group Chemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of materials 2.2.1 Preparation of CoP/NPC MP (0.2241 g) and CoCl2·6H2O (0.039 g) were added into 20 mL ultrapure water and then heated at 80 °C until all water evaporated (~3 h) to obtain powder. Then, the obtained powder was annealed in Ar atmosphere at 900 °C for 2 h with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The obtained black powder was pure CoP. 2.2.2 Preparation of d-CoP/NPC MP (0.2241 g), CoCl2·6H2O (0.039 g) and ZnCl2 (0.039 g) were added into 20 mL ultrapure water and then heated at 80 °C until all water evaporated (~3 h) to obtain powder. Then, the obtained powder was annealed in Ar atmosphere at 900 °C for 2 h with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The obtained black powder was soaked in 1 mol/L KOH overnight and filtered to obtain d-CoP/NPC rich in defects. 2.2.3 Preparation of Pt/d-CoP/NPC MP (0.2241 g), CoCl2·6H2O (0.039 g) and ZnCl2 (0.039 g) were added into 20 mL ultrapure water and then heated at 80 °C until all water evaporated (~3 h) to obtain powder. Then, the obtained powder was annealed in Ar atmosphere at 900 °C for 2 h with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The obtained black powder was soaked in 1 mol/L KOH for 12 h and then filtered to obtain d-CoP/NPC. Eventually, 10 mg of d-CoP/NPC and 0.94 mL of chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (5 mg/mL) (H2PtCl6·6H2O) were added into 10 mL of ethylene glycol (C2H6O2) and then heated at 65 °C in oil bath for 5 hours. The product was washed four times with the mixture of ethanol (5 mL) and acetone (10 mL). 2.2.4 Preparation of different molar ratios between MP and Co and between Co and Zn MP and CoCl2·6H2O (0.2241g MP and 0.078 g CoCl2·6H2O with molar ratio of 3:1, 0.2241 g MP and 0.039 g CoCl2·6H2O with molar ratio of 6:1, 0.2241 g MP and 0.02 g CoCl2·6H2O with molar ratio of 9:1) were added into 20 mL ultrapure water and then heated at 80 °C to obtain powder. Then, the obtained powder was annealed in Ar atmosphere at 900 °C for 2 h with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The obtained black powder for pure CoP. MP (0.2241 g), CoCl2·6H2O, ZnCl2 (0.039 g CoCl2·6H2O and 0.039 g ZnCl2 with quality ratio of 1:1, 0.039 g CoCl2·6H2O and 0.117 g ZnCl2 with quality ratio of 1:3, 0.039 g CoCl2·6H2O and 0.013 g ZnCl2 with quality ratio of 3:1) were added into 20 mL ultrapure water and then heated at 80 °C to obtain powder. Then, the obtained powder was annealed in Ar atmosphere at 900 °C for 2 h with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The obtained black powder was soaked in 1 mol/L KOH overnight and filtered to obtain d-CoP/NPC rich in defects. 2.3 Characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected on JEM-F200 and the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) images were collected on EDX-7000. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted on Regulus 8100. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was performed on Rigaku Ultima IV. Elemental compositions were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on Thermo Scientific K-Alpha. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was studied on JES-FA200. Raman spectroscopy was collected on Thermo Fischer DXR and in-situ Raman spectroscopy was collected on HR800. FTIR spectroscopy was collected on FTIR-7600. ICP measurement was obtained on NexION 300X. 2.3.1 Test procedure for Pt content in Pt/d-CoP/NPC About 0.1g was accurately weighed into 50 mL polytetrafluoroethylene digestion tube. The mass m1, m2 and m3 were recorded respectively. Add appropriate amount of inorganic acid (5 mL concentrated HNO3/1 mL HF) to the weighed sample digestion tube. Put the lid on and put it in the stainless steel reactor, put it in the oven to control the temperature of 190 °C for about 10 hours, then stop heating and cooling. Transfer the cooled solution to a 25 mL plastic volumetric flask and finally set the volume with deionized water. The standard test solution was prepared, and the standard solution was the national reference material. The concentration points of the curve were 0, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 5.0 mg/L, respectively. For instrument test, the calibration curve of standard solution was completed by instrument ICP-MS, and the sample mass and volume were input. Then the digested solution was tested sequentially, and the dilution beyond the curve range was tested again. Finally, the final content of measured elements in each sample was determined by spectrogram. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements 2.4.1 Electrodes preparation 20 μL of catalyst ink (2 mg of catalyst in 400 μL 5 wt% Nafion solution) was dropped onto the GCE (5 mm in diameter) with a loading of 510 μg/cm2 for all samples. Therefore, the concentration of the catalyst is 5 mg/mL. And the electrodes of Pt/C and RuO2 are also prepared using the same method. The Pt loading is 43.2 μgPt/cm2 for the Pt/d-CoP/NPC and 102 μgPt/cm2 for the Pt/C electrode. The Ru loading is 389.6 μgRu/cm2 for the RuO2 electrode. 2.4.2 Three-electrode system measurements Three-electrode system was used for electrochemical test in 1 mol/L KOH, 0.5 mol/L H2SO4, 1 mol/L PBS and 0.1 mol/L KOH on CHI-760E electrochemical workstation. The electrolytes that were used for the three-electrode system measurements had no saturated gas except that the ORR test was performed in 0.1 mol/L KOH solution with saturated O2. Carbon rod, reversible hydrogen electrode and glassy carbon electrode are utilized as counter electrode, reference electrode and working electrode, respectively. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was tested with a scan rate of 5 mV/s with 95% iR-correction. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out at different scan rates (20–120 mV s–1) in the non-faradaic potential range to estimate the electrochemical double layer capacitance (C dl). C dl = (j a – j c)/(2·v) = (j a + |j c|)/(2·v) = Δj/(2·v) where j a and j c is the anodic and cathodic current density, respectively, recorded at the middle of the selected potential range, and v is the scan rate. The electrochemical stability was evaluated by chronoamperometry measurements at a static overpotential. 2.4.3 Two-electrode system measurements The synthesized catalyst served as the anode and cathode with a scan rate of 5 mV/s in the range of 0.8–1.8 V for the overall splitting water. 2.4.4 ORR measurements The ORR mechanism was further examined with the Koutecky-Levich correlations by using the following equations: 1 d = 1 I k + 1 I d l = 1 I k + 1 B ω - 1 / 2 B = 0.2 n F C O 2 D O 2 2 / 3 θ O 2 - 1 / 6 In these equations, I d, I k and I dl are the disk current density, the kinetic current density and the diffusion limiting current density, respectively. Moreover, n is the electron transfer number, F is the Faraday constant (96485 C/mol), C O2 is the concentration of O2 in KOH solution (1.14×10–6 mol/cm3), D O2 is the oxygen diffusion coefficient in KOH (1.73×10–5 cm2/s) and υ is the kinematic viscosity of the KOH solution (0.01 cm2/s), ω is the electrode rotation rate (r/min). So there should be a linear relationship between 1/I d and ω –1/2, the intercept is equal to 1/I k, and the number of the electrons transferred during the reaction could be calculated from the slope [68]. The yield of H2O2 can be calculated by using the following equation: O O H - = 200 × I r / N I d + I r / N The I r is the ring current and I d is disk current. And the area of the ring is 0.1866 cm2 and the area of the disk is 0.2475 cm2. 2.4.5 Zn-air battery measurements Home-made liquid Zn-air batteries were assembled to assess the performance of the samples. It consists of polished zinc plate (0.20 mm thickness) as the anode and as-synthesized catalyst ink loaded on Ni foam (2 mg/cm2) as the air cathode. For primary Zn-air batteries, 6 mol/L KOH + 0.2 mol/L zinc acetate dehydrate was used as the electrolyte for rechargeable Zn-air batteries. Batteries were tested with CHI 760E electrochemical workstation. The charge-discharge cycle stability for rechargeable zinc-air battery was carried out with a cycling interval of 400 s (200 s for charging and 200 s for discharging). For pouch-type cell measurements, 3 g of PVA was dissolved in 30 mL of water, and then 3 mL of 18 mol/L of KOH and 0.2 mol/L of zinc acetate was added. The mixture was further stirred at 90 °C to form a transparent gel, and the gel and zinc foil were put in petri dish and frozen in refrigerator. As-synthesized catalyst ink was loaded on carbon cloth (2 mg/cm2) as the air cathode. The zinc foil coated with gel electrolyte and the air electrode were stacked together, and the pouch-type cell was encapsulated with breathable aluminum foil. 2.5 DFT Calculations All density functional theory calculations were performed by Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [69]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [70] functional was employed to treat the exchange-correlation interactions. The plane-wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV, the energy convergence criterion of 10–5 eV, the force convergence criterion of 0.02 eV Å−1, and a (2×2×1) Monkhorst-Pack k-point sampling was employed for structure relaxation. The Pt (111) was modeled by using a 4×4 supercell containing a slab of 5 layers. The CoP (211) was modeled by using a 2×2 supercell containing a slab of 4 layers. Pt cluster supported by CoP was used to stand for Pt/d-CoP/NPC. For different surface models, the bottom layer was fixed. A sufficiently large vacuum gap (> 10 Å) was employed to prevent the interaction between neighboring periodic structures. H2 and H2O were calculated in boxes of 20 Å×20 Å×20 Å with the gamma point only. In the alkaline medium, O2 is reduced as O2 + 2H2O (l) + 4e− → 4OH−, where the elementary reaction steps on the catalytic surface are: (1) O2 + 2H2O (l) + 4e− + s → OOH (s) + OH− + H2O (l) + 3e− (2) OOH (s) + 2OH− + H2O (l) + 3e− → 2OH (s) + 2OH− + 2e− (3) 2OH (s) + 2OH− + 2e− → OH (s) + 3OH− + e− (4) OH (s) + 3OH− + e− → 4OH− + s The free energies of H2O, O2 (g) and OH− are estimated from the following equations: (5) G H2O(l) = G H2O(g) + RTln(p/p 0) (6) G O2(g) = 2G H2O(l) + 2G H2 + 4.92eV (7) G OH– = G H2O(l) – G H+ = G H2O(l) – 1/2G H2 + K B Tln(10)×pH where R is the gas constant, T = 298.15 K, P = 0.035 bar and P 0 = 1 bar. The ORR overpotential (η ORR) as the key descriptor of the ORR catalytic activity. In the alkaline medium can be calculated as follows: η ORR = 0.402 +max(ΔG 1, ΔG 2, ΔG 3, ΔG 4)/e where the ΔG 1, ΔG 2, ΔG 3, ΔG 4, denote the Gibbs free energy change of reaction (1), (2), (3), and (4). The rate-determining step is O2 + 2H2O(l) + 4e− + s → OOH(s) + OH− + H2O(l) + 3e− for Pt/d-CoP/NPC and Pt (111). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Morphology and structural analysis The synthesis of Pt/d-CoP/NPC involves three steps (Fig. 1(a)). The mixture of MP, CoCl2·6H2O and ZnCl2 was first pyrolyzed at 900 °C. Then, the black powder was treated by potassium hydroxide solution to remove the Zn species and to form defect in CoP (d-CoP/NPC). Finally, oil bath was utilized to decorate Pt onto the d-CoP/NPC to achieve Pt/d-CoP/NPC. The phases of the composited catalyst were ascertained by XRD. As can be seen from Fig. 1(b) and Fig. S1, the synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC, d-CoP/NPC and CoP/NPC are composed of CoP (PDF#29-0497), but the three peaks observed at ~41°, ~43° and ~44° in the XRD pattern of CoP/NPC belong to the (121), (211) and (130) crystal faces of secondary phase Co2P (PDF#32-0306). The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) exhibits that the bulk morphology changed into small particles after reduction process (Fig. S2). The TEM images of Pt/d-CoP/NPC (Fig. 1(c) and Fig. S3) evidently illustrate that ultrafine Pt nanoparticles (marked with yellow circles) are homogeneously distributed onto CoP particles. The 0.19 nm spacing of lattice fringes in the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image corresponds to the (211) crystal plane of CoP (Fig. 1(d)). Moreover, atomic defects can be observed in the HRTEM (Fig. S4). Simultaneously, the EPR spectroscopy analysis also proves that more defects were generated after the etching of Zn, which can optimize the electrocatalytic performances (Fig. 1(e)) [71–73]. The high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) (Fig. S5) and the EDX mappings reveal the N, C, P, Pt and Co elements are evenly distributed in the synthesized catalyst, proving the existence of N, P doped carbon in Pt/d-CoP/NPC (Figs. 1(f)–(j)). The elements state and chemical components were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS survey spectrum demonstrates that the synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC is composed by Pt, Co, P, N and C and it is consistent with the result of EDX mappings (Fig. 2 (a)). The P 2p peaks at 129.3 (2p 3/2) and 130.1 eV (2p 1/2) for Pt/d-CoP/NPC are ascribed to P-M, verifying the existence of metal phosphide (Fig. 2(b)). The existence of the P–O bond (133.5 eV) can be ascribed to the exposure of the sample to air [74]. For the Co 2p 3/2 spectrum of d-CoP/NPC (Fig. 2(c)), three peaks are ascribed to Co3+ (778.5 eV), Co2+ (781.2 eV) and satellite peak at 785.3 eV [75,76]. Relative to d-CoP/NPC, the Co3+ 2p 3/2 and Co2+ 2p 3/2 peaks for Pt/d-CoP/NPC positively shifted by 0.2 and 0.5 eV, respectively, demonstrating the electronic interactions between Pt and CoP. Then, the peaks of Pt (74.8 and 71.5 eV) in Pt/d-CoP/NPC shifted negatively compared with commercial Pt/C owing to the electronegativity differences between cobalt and platinum (Fig. 2(d)), illustrating the transfer of electrons from cobalt to platinum (Fig. S6) [77,78]. The C 1s spectrum of Pt/d-CoP/NPC can be deconvolved into three peaks at 284.8, 286.2 and 288.8 eV which can be attributed to C–C, C–P and C–O (Fig. S7(a)) [79]. In the N 1s spectrum, the N–P and pyridinic-N species are detected at 397.5 and 399 eV, respectively (Fig. S7(b)) [80]. Similar peaks are observed in the prepared d-CoP/NPC (Figs. S7(c)–(e)) and confirm the formation of N, P-doped carbon in the Pt/d-CoP/NPC and d-CoP/NPC. Raman spectroscopy presents characteristic disordered carbon (D, ~1345 cm–1) and graphitic carbon (G, ~1583 cm–1) bands for carbon in the synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC and d-CoP/NPC (Fig. 2(e)). Pt/d-CoP/NPC and the d-CoP/NPC exhibit similar I D/I G values of 1.22 and 1.14, demonstrating the introduced Pt cannot affect the structure of the carbon matrix. Furthermore, the FTIR spectrum of Pt/d-CoP/NPC (Fig. 2(f)) displays peaks corresponding to P–O (~500 cm–1), N–P (940–1070 cm–1), C–C (~1630 cm–1), C–H (~2910 cm–1) and O–H (~3500 cm–1). 3.2 Electrochemical analysis of samples The ORR electrocatalytic activity of Pt/d-CoP/NPC and control samples was examined via LSV in 0.1 mol/L KOH. Fig. 3 (a) shows the ORR polarization curves of CoP/NPC, d-CoP/NPC, Pt/d-CoP/NPC and commercial Pt/C. Obviously, Pt/d-CoP/NPC possesses higher ORR catalytic performance than CoP/NPC and d-CoP/NPC. In particular, Pt/d-CoP/NPC presents a limiting current density of 5.9 mA/cm2, and half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.82 V. These values are superior to CoP/NPC (5.1 mA/cm2 and 0.45 V) and d-CoP/NPC (5.6 mA/cm2 and 0.71 V) and and comparable to Pt/C (6.3 mA/cm2 and 0.83 V). The j k for Pt/d-CoP/NPC at 0.85 V is 1.36 mA/cm2, which is higher than that for CoP/NPC (0.015 mA/cm2) and d-CoP/NPC (0.021 mA/cm2) and only surpassed by Pt/C (2.71 mA/cm2). The Tafel slope analysis is employed to investigate the reaction kinetics of the synthesized electrocatalysts (Fig. S8). It is obvious that the Pt/d-CoP/NPC displays the lowest Tafel slope of 34 mV/dec except for Pt/C (28 mV/dec), while the CoP/NPC and d-CoP/NPC present higher values of 63 and 45 mV/dec. As illustrated in Fig. 3(b) and Fig. S9, the current density exhibited a typical increasing trend with the rotating rate enhanced (from 400–1600 r/min), suggesting mass diffusion determined the ORR catalytic performance. Moreover, the K-L plots obtained stem from the LSVs exhibit a good linearity and the electron transfer numbers (n) are calculated to be close to 4 at different potentials (inset), demonstrating that the ORR process occurs through the ideal route. The electron number of 4 is also proved by the rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) measurement (Fig. S10). Fig. 3(c) displays that the Pt mass activity of Pt/d-CoP/NPC at 0.75 and 0.80 V overwhelmed commercial Pt/C. And the Pt mass content in Pt/d-CoP/NPC is 8.6 wt% by ICP test. The n is calculated to be 3.9 in the potential range of 0.1–0.8 V, and the H2O2 yield is as low as 0.85%, demonstrating the direct four-electron reaction pathway toward ORR (Fig. 3(d)). Except the excellent ORR performance of Pt/d-CoP/NPC, the stability is also assessed in O2 saturated alkaline media. As illustrated in Fig. 3(e), the current-time (i-t) test indicates that the as-synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC exhibits remarkable durability with negligible current density loss. And compared with other related works, it also has better catalytic activity (Fig. 3(f) and Table S1). DFT calculations were implemented to learn more about the origin of the excellent ORR activity for the synthesized electrocatalysts. The reaction mechanisms for ORR in alkaline medium of Pt/d-CoP/NPC and Pt are illustrated in Fig. 4 (a) and Fig. S11. In line with the XPS result, the charge transferred from CoP to Pt, thus favoring the activation of oxygen molecule to boost the catalytic process (Fig. 4(b)). Free energy diagrams of the intermediates during the ORR process were compared for different models to study the distinct catalytic activities of the synthesized electrocatalysts (Fig. 4(c) and Fig. S12(a)). The rate determining step for Pt/d-CoP/NPC and Pt/C is the first step, and the synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC possesses favorable thermodynamic overpotential, verifying its highly efficient ORR performance. Additionally, the partial density of states (DOS) of *OO intermediate adsorption onto Pt and Pt/d-CoP/NPC were calculated to evaluate the binding strength. Fig. 4(d) shows that the d band center of Pt in Pt/d-CoP/NPC presents evidently positive shift to the Fermi level relative to the pure Pt, demonstrating the introduced CoP could lead to the delocalized electron redistribution, thus optimizing the adsorption of the reaction intermediates (Fig. S12(b)). The ORR overpotential (η ORR) is the key descriptor of the ORR catalytic activity. According to the DFT calculations of the Gibbs free energy, the η ORRPt, η ORRPt/d-CoP/NPC and η ORRCoP/NPC are 0.602, 0.422 and 1.082 V, respectively. As a critical half-reaction for water-splitting and rechargeable metal-air batteries, the OER was also tested in on the synthesized electrocatalysts in 1 mol/L KOH. Significantly, the synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC exhibits superior catalytic activity to the reference samples including commercial RuO2 (Fig. 5 (a)). Specially, Pt/d-CoP/NPC reaches 10 and 100 mA/cm2 at 320 and 410 mV, severally, which is lower than CoP/NPC (500 mV at 10 mA/cm2), d-CoP/NPC (360 and 440 mV) and RuO2 (330 and 470 mV) (Inset of Fig. 5(a)). Moreover, the Tafel slope (72 mV/dec) of Pt/d-CoP/NPC is lower than that of CoP/NPC (106 mV/dec), d-CoP/NPC (82 mV/dec) and RuO2 (78 mV/dec), verifying the rapid reaction kinetics (Fig. S13(a)). Remarkably, the chronoamperometry measurement demonstrates that Pt/d-CoP/NPC owns excellent long-term stability in terms of the negligible current density decrease (Fig. S13(b)). And after a 24 h stability test, the overpotential increased only 23 mV at 50 mA/cm2, demonstrating the outstanding stability of the synthesized electrocatalyst (Fig. S13(c)). XPS and XRD measurements were performed on the post-OER Pt/d-CoP/NPC (Fig. S14). The XRD characterization of Pt/d-CoP/NPC shows that the composition of the sample has negligible changes. It is worth noting that the Co at the surface underwent oxidation during the prolonged OER as the relative content of Co3+ increased. With the remarkable electrocatalytic activities toward OER and ORR, Pt/d-CoP/NPC was utilized as the electrode material for rechargeable liquid Zn-air battery (ZAB, Fig. 5(b)). As shown in Fig. 5(c), the assembled ZAB constructed by Pt/d-CoP/NPC possesses a large open-circuit voltage of 1.39 V with a narrow voltage gap (Fig. 5(d)). Moreover, the obtained ZAB also achieves a high-up peak power density of 182.8 mW/cm2, which is comparable or better than those delivered by the recently reported catalysts (Fig. 5(e) and Table S2). Long term stability is also a paramount factor on determining the practical applications of the self-assembled ZAB. Galvanostatic discharge-charge cycling measurements were conducted at a constant current density of 10 mA/cm2. As shown in Fig. 5(f), the ZAB using Pt/d-CoP/NPC electrode presents a negligible voltage increase over 200 h, verifying its remarkable cycling stability. Also, we made our own bagged flexible battery which had an open circuit voltage of 1.24 V (Fig. S15). After 45 h of successive cycling, the voltage gap changed very little (Fig. 5(g)). Interestingly, no matter what angle it is folded at (0–180°), the self-assembled pouched battery keeps the little fan spinning (Fig. 5(h)). Catalyzing HER at the cathode is significant for hydrogen generation via overall water-splitting. The electrocatalytic performances of the as-designed samples toward HER were first studied in 1 mol/L KOH via LSV with a scanning rate of 5 mV/s. Fig. 6 (a) shows the LSVs of CoP/NPC, d-CoP/NPC, Pt/d-CoP/NPC and Pt/C. Strikingly, the as-synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC owns the smallest overpotential of 33 mV to reach 10 mA/cm2 and the largest current density of 22.6 mA/cm2 at the specific potential of 50 mV, which is better than those of comparative samples and the commercial Pt/C (Fig. S16(a)). Moreover, Pt/d-CoP/NPC exhibits the smallest Tafel slope of 24 mV/dec compared with CoP/NPC (72 mV/dec), d-CoP/NPC (69 mV/dec) and the most advanced Pt/C (38 mV/dec), demonstrating the improved kinetics of Pt/d-CoP/NPC for alkaline HER (Fig. S16(b)). The HER performance of Pt/d-CoP/NPC is comparable with some recently published values for HER in alkaline electrolyte (Fig. S16(c) and Table S3). The double layer capacitance (C dl) was also obtained by cyclic voltammetry to assess the electrochemical surface area of the as-prepared electrocatalysts (Fig. S18). Obviously, the value of C dl increased to 10 mF/cm2 for Pt/d-CoP/NPC after both cationic defects and Pt were introduced, demonstrating the high exposure of active sites during electrocatalytic process (Fig. 6(b)). Apart from the splendid catalytic activity, the synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC also presents remarkable stability without evident current decay after a continuous 24 h test (Fig. S16(d)), and the overpotential increased by only 3 mV at –25 mA/cm2 (Fig. S17).The in situ Raman spectroscopy measurements were conducted to probe the bearing between the HER activity of Pt/d-CoP/NPC and its water adsorption capacity. Pt/d-CoP/NPC showed the peak intensity at 1650 cm−1 (H–O–H) and 3500 cm–1 (interfacial water), demonstrating the first-rate water adsorption capacity (Fig. 6(c)). The catalytic activities of the developed electrocatalysts are also studied in acid electrolyte owing to the good reaction kinetics toward HER. As illustrated in Fig. 6(d) and Fig. S19(a), Pt/d-CoP/NPC also exhibits the most remarkable electrocatalytic performance for HER in 0.5 mol/L H2SO4 with the smallest overpotentials of 6 and 15 mV at 10 and 50 mA/cm2, superior to CoP/NPC (185 and 240 mV), d-CoP/NPC (171 and 221 mV) and Pt/C (12 and 39 mV). Moreover, Pt/d-CoP/NPC delivers the smallest Tafel slope of 12 mV/dec relative to CoP/NPC (56 mV/dec), d-CoP/NPC (52 mV/dec) and Pt/C (21 mV/dec), demonstrating the spanking reaction rate and advantageous reaction kinetics toward HER in acid media (Fig. 6(e)). These values are superior to most of the recently published Pt-based electrocatalysts (Fig. 6(f) and Table S4). The designed Pt/d-CoP/NPC displays stable current density during the long-running measurement, demonstrating its outstanding durability in acid electrolyte (Fig. S19(b)) and the overpotential increased by only 5 mV at –25 mA/cm2 (Fig. S20). Moreover, the obtained C dl demonstrates that the prepared Pt/d-CoP/NPC exposes the most abundant active sites for HER (Figs. S19(c) and S21). Based on ICP analysis, the mass activity of Pt/d-CoP/NPC was determined to be 4.42 A/mg at η = 50 mV, thus outperforming Pt/C (Fig. S19(d)). Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were recorded on a fixed potential of –20 mV vs. RHE, and these show that Pt/d-CoP/NPC (1.4 Ω) possesses a smaller charge transfer resistance than CoP/NPC (1760 Ω), d-CoP/NPC (52.4 Ω) and the commercial Pt/C (3.4 Ω) verifying its favorable electroconductivity and reaction kinetics (Fig. S22). Relative to alkaline and acid electrolytes, a neutral medium is more gentle and ecofriendly toward water-splitting. Notably, Pt/d-CoP/NPC affords excellent HER performance in 1 mol/L PBS (70 mV) relative to d-CoP/NPC (295 mV) and the commercial Pt/C (81 mV) at 10 mA/cm2, confirming that Pt/d-CoP/NPC is an active electrocatalyst toward HER in neutral solution (Fig. 6(g)). The small Tafel slope of Pt/d-CoP/NPC (36 mV/dec) also demonstrates its fast reaction kinetics for HER (Fig. 6(h)). As illustrated in Fig. 6(i), the Pt/d-CoP/NPC delivered excellent operation stability as long as 24 h with negligible current density decay and the overpotential increased 31 mV at –25 mA/cm2 (Fig. S23). The HER performance of Pt/d-CoP/NPC is comparable with some recently published values for HER in neutral electrolyte (Fig. S24(a) and Table S5). Identically, the introduced cationic defects and Pt endow the synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC with the maximal C dl value of 9 mF/cm2 to provide rich active sites (Figs. S24(b) and S25). In addition, different ratios MP/Co and Co/Zn are investigated on regulating the catalytic performances (Fig. S26). As mentioned above, the prepared Pt/d-CoP/NPC presents superior performances for both HER and OER in alkaline electrolytes. Then, a two-electrode electrolyzer in 1 mol/L KOH was assembled with Pt/d-CoP/NPC as both the anode and cathode for water-splitting. Remarkably, the Pt/d-CoP/NPC required a low cell voltage of 1.53 and 1.66 V to drive the current density of 10 and 100 mA/cm2, respectively, which is lower than that of Pt/C || RuO2 couple (1.55 and 1.75 V), verifying its splendid catalytic activity toward hydrogen generation (Fig. 7 (a)). The cell voltage of Pt/d-CoP/NPC has more advantage than most of the recently published bifunctional electrocatalysts (Fig. 7(b) and Table S6) [81–92]. Moreover, the Pt/d-CoP/NPC pair also possesses excellent long-term stability with unattenuated current density for water-splitting over 10 h (Fig. 7(c)). The Stirling engine can be driven by overall water-splitting using Pt/d-CoP/NPC || Pt/d-CoP/NPC (Fig. 7(d) and Movie S1). Owing to the small cell voltage, the electrolyzer can be driven by an AAA battery with sumless bubbles generated on both the anode and cathode (Fig. S27(a) and Movie S2). Interestingly, sustainable energies (wind energy, solar energy) can also urge the overall water-splitting with abundant gases produced on the two electrode, suggesting its potential for converting the intermittent energies into hydrogen energy (Fig. 7(e) and Movie S3, Fig. S27(b) and Movie S4). The two-electrode electrolytic cell can be also powered by the self-assembled flexible Zn-air battery (Fig. 7(f)). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the efficient catalyst of Pt/d-CoP/NPC with abundant defect-related active sites is synthesized by a simple and convenient pyrolysis/chemical reduction method. The synthesized catalyst exhibits excellent full-pH HER and basic OER and ORR performances that are applied in a two-electrode device of overall water splitting and rechargeable Zn-air battery. The fabulous performance of Pt/d-CoP/NPC is precisely due to the existence of defects in CoP, which adjust the electron density at the Pt|CoP interface, increase the electrical conductivity of CoP, and improve the intrinsic activity and adsorption properties of Pt. Moreover, overall water splitting using electrolysis cells composed of Pt/d-CoP/NPC as the anode and cathode can be promoted by sustainable energy, such as solar energy, wind energy and thermal energy. Hopefully, the synthesis of Pt/d-CoP/NPC will provide methods and avenues for multifunctionalization of electrocatalytic nanomaterials. coredata.dc:description: Developing multifunctional electrocatalysts toward energy-related reactions could reduce the cost and improve the utilization efficiency of raw materials. Herein, defective CoP decorated with ultrafine Pt nanoparticles (Pt/d-CoP/NPC) with multifunctional electrocatalytic performances is prepared via facile pyrolysis and following chemical reduction process. The as-synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC owns high half-wave potential of 0.82 V for oxygen reduction reaction with excellent stability in 0.1 mol/L KOH. Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that the adsorption energy of *OO at Pt/d-CoP/NPC is stronger compared to Pt, yielding higher catalytic activity for ORR. Moreover, the resultant electrocatalyst possesses excellent catalytic activities with low overpotentials toward hydrogen evolution reaction (33 mV in 1 mol/L KOH, 6 mV in 0.5 mol/L H2SO4 and 70 mV in 1 mol/L PBS) and oxygen evolution reaction (320 mV) at 10 mA/cm2. Water-splitting and rechargeable Zn-air batteries assembled with the as-synthesized Pt/d-CoP/NPC as electrodes exhibit outstanding activity and long-range stability. Remarkably, sustainable energies and homemade Zn-air battery can efficiently drive the Pt/d-CoP/NPC electrolyzer with sumless hydrogen bubbles generated, verifying the potential applications for renewable energy storage.

coredata.dc:title: Surface-enriched ultrafine Pt nanoparticles coupled with defective CoP as efficient trifunctional electrocatalyst for overall water splitting and flexible Zn-air battery
